questions.question: At what minimum voltage of static electricity can you feel an ESD shock?
questions.explanation: A person can feel ESD at a minimum of 3,000 volts. Less than 30 volts can damage computer components, but you won't feel it.

questions.question: Which component is most susceptible to damage from ESD?
questions.explanation: RAM modules and other semiconductor components are highly sensitive to ESD damage. The computer case and cables are not as susceptible.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an antistatic wrist strap?
options: To protect the technician from electrical shock
To ground the technician to prevent ESD damage
To improve grip when handling components
To monitor heart rate during repairs
questions.explanation: An antistatic wrist strap grounds the technician to prevent electrostatic discharge from damaging sensitive computer components.

questions.question: Which motherboard form factor is most commonly used in desktop computers?
questions.explanation: ATX (Advanced Technology Extended) is the most common motherboard form factor for desktop computers, providing a good balance of size and expansion capabilities.

questions.question: What two components on the motherboard control system boot operations? (Choose two)
questions.explanation: The BIOS chip and UEFI chip are responsible for controlling system boot operations. Note: This is a multi-answer question - both BIOS and UEFI would be correct.

questions.question: Which component contains the basic instructions needed to boot the computer and load the operating system?
questions.explanation: ROM (Read-Only Memory) containing the BIOS/UEFI stores the basic instructions needed to boot the computer and load the operating system.

questions.question: What is the purpose of thermal compound?
options: To conduct heat from the CPU to the heat sink
To secure the CPU in place
questions.explanation: Thermal compound (thermal paste) is applied between the CPU and heat sink to improve heat transfer by filling microscopic gaps between the surfaces.

questions.question: Which type of memory loses its contents when the computer is powered off?
questions.explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) is volatile memory that loses its contents when power is removed. ROM, CMOS, and BIOS retain their data.

questions.question: What ensures that memory modules are inserted correctly into memory slots?
options: A notch in the module aligned with a notch in the slot
The module only fits one way
questions.explanation: Memory modules have a notch that must align with a corresponding notch in the memory slot, ensuring proper orientation and preventing incorrect installation.

questions.question: Which power connector is used to supply power to modern motherboards?
questions.explanation: Modern motherboards use a 24-pin ATX power connector as the main power connection. Older boards used 20-pin connectors.

questions.question: What type of expansion slot is typically used for graphics cards in modern computers?
questions.explanation: PCIe x16 (PCI Express x16) slots are the standard for modern graphics cards, providing high bandwidth for graphics processing.

questions.question: Which storage device has no moving parts?
questions.explanation: Solid state drives (SSDs) use flash memory and have no moving parts, making them faster, more durable, and quieter than mechanical drives.

questions.question: What is the standard interface for connecting modern hard drives and SSDs to the motherboard?
questions.explanation: SATA (Serial ATA) is the standard interface for connecting internal storage devices like hard drives and SSDs to modern motherboards.

questions.question: Which component supplies DC power to all components inside the computer?
questions.explanation: The power supply unit (PSU) converts AC power from the wall outlet to the various DC voltages needed by computer components.

questions.question: What voltage does a CMOS battery typically provide?
questions.explanation: CMOS batteries typically provide 3V DC to maintain BIOS settings and system clock when the computer is powered off.

questions.question: Which port is commonly used for connecting external storage devices and peripherals?
questions.explanation: USB (Universal Serial Bus) is the most common port for connecting external storage devices, peripherals, and many other devices.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the chipset on a motherboard?
options: Control communication between CPU and other components
questions.explanation: The chipset manages data flow between the CPU, memory, and peripheral devices, essentially controlling communication throughout the system.

questions.question: When building a PC that needs to support eSATA, which component should be checked for compatibility?
questions.explanation: The chipset determines which features and interfaces are supported by the motherboard, including eSATA support.

questions.question: What type of memory modules are used in desktop tower computers?
questions.explanation: Desktop tower computers use DIMM (Dual Inline Memory Module) for RAM. SODIMMs are used in laptops.

questions.question: Which cooling method is most effective for high-performance CPUs?
questions.explanation: Liquid cooling systems provide the most effective cooling for high-performance CPUs by efficiently transferring heat away from the processor.

questions.question: What is the purpose of standoffs in computer case installation?
options: To prevent the motherboard from shorting against the case
questions.explanation: Standoffs create space between the motherboard and case, preventing electrical shorts from the motherboard's circuits touching the metal case.

questions.question: Which component failure is typically indicated by a pattern of beeps during POST?
questions.explanation: POST (Power-On Self-Test) uses beep codes to indicate hardware failures, commonly memory problems or other critical component issues.

questions.question: What is the maximum data transfer rate of USB 3.0?
questions.explanation: USB 3.0 (also known as USB 3.1 Gen 1) has a maximum theoretical transfer rate of 5 Gbps, which is 10 times faster than USB 2.0.

questions.question: Which type of RAM must be installed in matched pairs for dual-channel operation?
questions.explanation: For optimal dual-channel operation, RAM modules should be identical in capacity, speed, and timings. Matched pairs ensure proper synchronization.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of an M.2 SSD over a 2.5-inch SATA SSD?
options: Smaller form factor and potentially faster speeds
questions.explanation: M.2 SSDs offer a much smaller form factor and can use NVMe protocol for significantly faster speeds than SATA SSDs.

questions.question: Which power rail provides the primary power for modern CPUs?
questions.explanation: Modern CPUs receive their primary power from the +12V rail, which is then regulated down to the required voltage by the motherboard's VRM.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Safety Data Sheet (SDS)?
options: To summarize hazardous material information and disposal methods
questions.explanation: An SDS provides information about hazardous materials, including health effects, fire hazards, first-aid requirements, and safe disposal methods.

questions.question: Which video output provides the best quality for modern displays?
questions.explanation: DisplayPort provides the highest bandwidth and supports the highest resolutions and refresh rates, making it ideal for modern high-end displays.

questions.question: What component stores BIOS/UEFI settings when the computer is powered off?
questions.explanation: CMOS memory, powered by the CMOS battery, stores BIOS/UEFI settings, system time, and hardware configuration when the system is powered off.

questions.question: Which factor does NOT affect CPU performance?
questions.explanation: CMOS battery voltage only maintains BIOS settings and does not affect CPU performance. Clock speed, cores, and cache directly impact performance.

questions.question: What is the standard voltage for PCIe slot power?
questions.explanation: PCIe slots provide both +3.3V and +12V power rails. High-power devices like graphics cards primarily use the +12V rail.

questions.question: Which component directly executes program instructions?
questions.explanation: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) is responsible for executing program instructions and performing calculations.

questions.question: What happens when the CMOS battery fails?
options: BIOS settings and system time are lost
questions.explanation: When the CMOS battery fails, the system loses BIOS settings and system time/date when powered off, but the computer can still boot.

questions.question: Which interface provides the fastest data transfer for internal storage?
questions.explanation: NVMe over PCIe provides the fastest data transfer rates for internal storage, significantly outperforming SATA-based interfaces.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a grounded mat on a workbench?
options: To prevent ESD damage to components
questions.explanation: A grounded mat (antistatic mat) on a workbench provides an ESD-safe surface for working on sensitive electronic components.
